title: Government to wipe historic homosexual convictions - Yahoo7
text:
Share Government to wipe historic homosexual convictions - Yahoo7 The government has announced that historic convictions for sex between men in New Zealand will be quashed. Close 'Suffered tremendous hurt and stigma': Goverment to wipe historic homosexual convictions UP NEXT VIDEO 'Suffered tremendous hurt and stigma': Goverment to wipe historic homosexual convictions. Source: 1 News 'Suffered tremendous hurt and stigma': Goverment to wipe historic homosexual convictions 
Justice Minister Amy Adams made the announcement on Thursday afternoon, with the move allowing people convicted before the homosexual law reform in 1986 to have their convictions removed. 
People with convictions for specific offences relating to consensual sexual activity between men 16 years and over will be eligible to apply to the Secretary of Justice to have the conviction wiped. 
However, Adams said those who committed acts which are still illegal today are not included. 
"The acts were illegal at the time - obviously that is not the view of society now, and I would agree with that, but at the time they were criminal offending and we judge criminality by the law at the time," she said. Adams said a blanket rule would not work, instead a case-by-case process is best. Photo: SNPA 
The Ministry of Justice estimates around 879 people were convicted of homosexual acts before legalisation in 1986, with around 80 per cent are believed to have convictions that would still be offences today. 
Adams said while the impact on their lives cannot be changed, she hoped the move is a step in the right direction. 
"Although we can never fully undo the impact on the lives of those affected, this new scheme will provide a pathway for their convictions to be expunged. 
"It means people will be treated as if they had never been convicted, and removes the ongoing stigma and prejudice that can arise from convictions for homosexual offences. 
â€œI acknowledge the pain that these New Zealanders have lived with and hope that this will go some way toward addressing that. 
"We are absolutely recognising our sorrow and we are sorry." The move is a win for the LGBT community who have been calling for the change. Photo: Getty 
The policy change in New Zealand comes after Britain agreed in October to pardon thousands of gay and bisexual men convicted under obsolete legislation. 
The scheme is set to begin in 2018 - as soon as the necessary law changes are in place. 
If a person's application is approved, government records will be amended so the conviction does not appear in criminal history checks and they will be entitled to declare they have no such conviction. 
Decisions will be made by the secretary of justice, without the need for formal court hearings or for applicants to appear in person. 
ACT leader David Seymour has praised the Government's move, saying it's "absolutely the right thing to do".
